pros: PNCA is a small art and design college of 500 + students in a Portland. The community consists of faculty, staff, public galleries, programs and exhibitions. It is a place with new leadership that is focused on growing school enrollment, expanding support for students and building a caring environment for staff.
cons: Like many employers in Portland it is recovering from financial and social impacts of COVID on the school and the surrounding downtown community (houseless community) etc. This is a wider Portland issue and not PNCA.

review_title: Low ambition, low compensation, low results
pros: There is very little positive about this school. As a public service, it should be permanently closed down.
cons: PNCA is unranked in US News and World Report. Salaries are 30-50% lower than average institutions. The acceptance rate at PNCA is close to 90%. The graduation rate is low. Student outcomes are abysmal, not even local companies such as Nike or Weiden + Kennedy will hire graduates. Most of the faculty are simply failed artists who sacrifice ethics and integrity to save their job, knowing that they cannot get hired anywhere else on earth.

pros: The students are wonderful. The admin and faculty talk about inclusivity in valuable ways, but never truly practice it.
cons: The admin and their politics trickle down to the faculty hoarding the little power they have and this creates a working environment akin to Lord of the Flies. Staff/faculty who should be taking a stand for a myriad of ethical reasons are not. It's a truly terrible place to work and the students are acutely aware of the inequities at the admin/faculty level which they see also impacting their own educational experiences.

pros: Friendly and communicative students, good faculty and HR. Easy to work with coworkers.
cons: Difficult working conditions for Safety because of downtime environment.

pros: The students are great, depending on your chair there is a lot of flexibility in how to run your class. You get to work with cool people.
cons: The school is constantly trying to get more students, it can be unorganized and communication can be difficult.

review_title: Does their Best and full of great people
pros: Amazing coworkers and great opportunity to work in the midst of exciting cultural and educational practices.
cons:
Resource scarcity common in higher ed and arts organizations is definitely present here.
Benefit of flexibility and reflexiveness in my team is also a con because there is a lack of stable and transparent org structure at times.

pros: Not much oversight from supervisors. Free to improvise and be creative.
cons: No pay raises; diminishing benefits; not a friendly environment for BIPoC; mostly White staff and faculty, all White executives; lots of egos.

pros:
Fun co-workers, never boring, decent benefits, and tuition waivers.
Campus is in city center and close to public transportation hubs.
cons:
Low pay and no cost of living adjustments (three years ago was last COLA. And it had been three years before that...).
The Board and Senior Staff do not prioritize addressing compensation issues--this issue is over a decade old with no effort towards resolution.
Lack of institutional support for training/professional development.
Many departments are understaffed.

review_title: Unless you have an independent income stream, a high-earning spouse, or your house paid off already, don't work at PNCA.
pros: Creative colleagues and students. High energy environment. Good visiting artists/academics.
cons: Pay scales date back to a prior economy, and do not correspond with current economic realities. Workloads are unrealistic, even for part-time faculty. There is a culture of self-sacrifice that keeps the college going, but requires, well, self-sacrifice on behalf of everybody.

pros: None, zilch. Oh wait...nope nothing. People do drink a lot at work there I guess. I think it's the only way they get through the constant threat of losing their jobs or the stifling anything proactive they do to try to help the school.
cons: Nepotistic, unwarranted self-aggrandizing, management thinks they know how to do every job and stifle any creativity which is ironic because their last campaign was entitled "Creativity Works Here". It very much does not.

review_title: Sooner or later, it will get to you.
pros:
-Free pizza during some student events.
-A monastic lifestyle where you can train yourself to simply  "do without". Get back to the basics.
-Never having to face a performance review.
-No drug test.
cons:
-Dartboard-style management of the school's money.
-Not being able to look a student in the eye and tell them they're learning marketable skills.
-Cronyism that goes all the way to the top.
-Watching valued (and sometimes, critical) staff leave.

review_title: Great building and students, poor workplace
job_title: Senior Admissions Counselor in Portland, OR
pros: Occasionally relaxed atmosphere, great architecture, interesting students to work with
cons: Poor leadership, poor salary, working in a bubble

pros: Great team environment and some of the most interesting people! Really passionate about art + design. A lot of opportunity to contribute to the institution. Awesome benefits.
cons: Long hours can be tough, but ultimately the work is rewarding so its not too bad.

pros: Teaching creative students is, of course, compelling
cons: No job security, no benefits, semester-length contracts, no input re: job assignments, no seniority, constantly shifting policies, constantly shifting administrative team, extremely low morale, extremely high tuition, poor facilities

review_title: What a scam! Sorry Students! Transfer out now!
cons: The president is terrible and grossly over paid. Management is terrible and bitter.

pros: Employees are great, helpful, committed, knowlegable.
cons: Terrible pay, elitist top management, irresponsible fiscal management, unethical behavior, duping the public about :success"!
